Part 1.Title: Cellular composition of dedifferentiated liposarcomas
Part 1.Reason: This part provides a detailed protocol for collecting and processing fresh tumor samples, which is directly relevant to your research objective of analyzing differences in metabolic characteristics between highly differentiated and dedifferentiated liposarcoma.
Part 1.Suggestions: You can use the methods for data collection and sample preparation, tissue dissociation, cell isolation, and quality control of single-cell suspensions. The datasets mentioned (11 primary untreated DDLPS patients and additional adipocytic tumors and normal adipose tissues) can be used for comparison. Modifications may include adjusting the sample size to fit your available resources and ensuring compatibility with your RNA sequencing data. Additionally, perform a detailed cost analysis to ensure the methods fit within the 200,000 RMB funding. Consider integrating publicly available datasets to enhance the robustness of your analysis.

Part 2.Title: Diversity of myeloid and lymphoid cells in adipocytic tumors
Part 2.Reason: While this part focuses on immune cell diversity, which is not the primary focus of your research, it provides useful techniques for identifying and characterizing cell subtypes using scRNA-seq and marker gene identification.
Part 2.Suggestions: You can learn from the methods used for scRNA-seq data analysis, marker gene identification, and characterization of cell populations. These techniques can be applied to analyze metabolic characteristics in your samples. Modifications may include focusing on metabolic-related markers instead of immune cell markers. Integrate publicly available datasets that focus on metabolic pathways to enhance the robustness of your analysis. Provide a detailed cost analysis to ensure the methods fit within the available funding.

Part 3.Title: Tumor cell heterogeneity in DDLPS
Part 3.Reason: This part is highly relevant as it deals with identifying tumor cell clusters, gene expression profiling, and pathway analysis, which are crucial for understanding metabolic differences between highly differentiated and dedifferentiated liposarcoma.
Part 3.Suggestions: You can use the methods for identifying tumor cell clusters, gene expression and pathway analysis, and differential gene expression between WD and DD tumor cells. The datasets mentioned can be used to validate your findings. Modifications may include focusing on metabolic pathways and using your RNA sequencing data for validation. Highlight specific metabolic pathways of interest and provide detailed suggestions for identifying and analyzing these pathways. Perform a detailed cost analysis to ensure the methods fit within the available funding.

Part 4.Title: DDLPS originate from adipocyte stromal progenitor cells
Part 4.Reason: This part provides insights into the origin of DDLPS and the characterization of progenitor cells, which can be useful for understanding the metabolic characteristics of tumor cells.
Part 4.Suggestions: You can use the methods for integrating tumor cells, comparing gene expression profiles with known progenitor cell signatures, and validating findings using immunohistochemistry and in situ multiplex immunofluorescence. Modifications may include focusing on metabolic markers and pathways relevant to your research objective. Ensure that the methods are feasible within the given funding and computational resources. Integrate publicly available datasets to enhance the robustness of your analysis.

Part 5.Title: Genomic evolution of DDLPS
Part 5.Reason: This part focuses on genomic analysis, which can provide context for metabolic differences but is not the primary focus of your research.
Part 5.Suggestions: You can use the methods for DNA extraction, library preparation, sequencing, and data analysis to complement your RNA-seq data. Modifications may include focusing on genomic regions related to metabolism and integrating genomic data with RNA-seq data. Provide a detailed cost analysis to ensure the methods fit within the available funding. Integrate publicly available datasets to enhance the robustness of your analysis.

Part 6.Title: DD tumor cells keep the biological properties of their progenitors
Part 6.Reason: This part provides valuable information on the differentiation properties of tumor cells, which can be relevant for understanding metabolic characteristics.
Part 6.Suggestions: You can use the methods for establishing PDX models, differentiation assays, and analyzing the effects of TGF-Î² on differentiation. Modifications may include focusing on metabolic differentiation assays and using your RNA-seq data to validate findings.
